Title:
Realignment of the genera of Cleveaceae (Marchantiopsida,
Marchantiidae)
Abstract:
A molecular study was carried out to test the
circumscription of the genera within the complex thalloid liverwort
family Cleveaceae and their relationships. Nucleotide sequence data from
three chloroplast genes (psbA, rpoC1 and rps4) were assembled for 41
accessions of Cleveaceae (ingroup) and 6 accessions representing 6
species from the family Aytoniaceae (outgroup), to construct the first
molecular phylogeny for the family. Traditionally three genera
(Athalamia, Peltolepis and Sauteria) have been recognized in Cleveaceae
but analyses of the molecular data support the recognition of four
genera. Peltolepis and Sauteria are supported as previously defined but
Athalamia is resolved as polyphyletic and the genus Clevea is therefore
segregated from it and a narrower Athalamia distinguished from it. The
traditional definition of genera of Cleveaceae largely by two characters
(carpocephalum stalk position and anatomy) is rejected and morphological
characters defining the genera are re-assessed. From this a revised
generic delimitation is presented, including a key. Evolution of the
genera of Cleveaceae is re-evaluated in the light of molecular results
and the misleading influence of homoplasy on past phylogenies is
discussed.
